conclusion: The relationship between the volume V of an ideal gas and the temperature T is shown; pressure in state A is pA=p0, temperature TA=T0.
Line segment AB is parallel to the V-axis, indicating constant volume.
Volume remains constant while temperature increases.
According to Charles' Law, at constant pressure, volume changes with temperature.
Since volume is constant, pressure must increase proportionally with temperature.
If temperature doubles, pressure also doubles.
Given pressure in state A is p0 and temperature is T0, pressure in state B with temperature 2T0 is 2p0.
